Literature Review: Riboflavin, a water-soluble B vitamin, plays a crucial role in various bodily functions, including energy metabolism, cellular antioxidant potential, and metabolic interactions with other micronutrients. Severe riboflavin deficiency, largely confined to low-income countries, can lead to a range of clinical manifestations, including cheilosis, angular stomatitis, glossitis, seborrheic dermatitis, and severe anemia with erythroid hypoplasia (1). Subclinical deficiency may be more widespread, including in high-income countries, but typically goes undetected due to the lack of measurement of riboflavin biomarkers in human studies (2). The consequences of low and deficient riboflavin status throughout the life cycle are significant, including anemia and hypertension, which could substantially contribute to the global burden of disease (3, 4). This review aims to summarize the available evidence on causes, detection, and consequences of riboflavin deficiency, ranging from clinical deficiency signs to manifestations associated with less severe deficiency, and to discuss related research, public health, and policy priorities (5).
